text: Hi, everyone.

My name is Daphne Baldassari,
and I'm a doctoral candidate
at the University of Toronto.

And today, I'm going
to show you one

of the chapter of
my dissertation

where I examine how a diversity
intervention by an evaluator

influences hiring decision
in the film industry

with the evaluator being
none other than the Academy
of Motion Pictures.

So as you may know, awards
hold substantial sway

in today's market, shaping the
allocation of opportunities,
attention, and resources.

Consequently, many
organizations actively

seek awards for themselves
or their employees.

Nevertheless, there
have been concerns

about the gender and
racial inequalities

that exist in the
award processes,

resulting in adverse
consequences for historically
marginalized workers.

Activists and
practitioners often

advocate to actually diversify
award committees and evaluation

committees to try to
address this problem.

But while prior research has
mainly focused on the direct

effect-- that is, how
it influences who wins,
who gets nominated--

I want to focus on what I call
the indirect hiring effects--

that is, how award-seeking
organizations actually
adjust their hiring processes.

And specifically,
I theorize that

an award-seeking organization
will respond to such a change

because the award-granting
organization signals

a change in how diversity
and inclusion is now valued.

So to study this
effect, I set my study

in the Academy of
Motion Pictures.

In 2015 and 2016, only
white actors and actresses
were nominated to the Oscars.

And the president of
the Academy at the time

really felt compelled
to take action
to this real structural problem.

And they led what was called
the A2020 intervention,

an intervention to drastically
increase the number of women

and racial minority
among Oscar voters.

So on the graph on the
left, you can see this bump

in the number of
people invited to join

the Academy and the large
proportion of people
of color invited to join.

And to identify those
indirect effects, what I did

is I partnered with
Luminate Film and TV data

to have all of the hiring
decisions on film productions
between 2010 and 2021.

And one cool aspect of this data
is that I do not only observe

the above-the-line
occupation-- that is,

the creative occupation that
lead the direction on a movie
and are the most visible--

but I also observe the less
visible occupation-- that
is, the technical occupations.

And in my research design to
disentangle the general trends

of diversity and
inclusion from the film

industry from the
intervention itself, what I do

is I compare hiring decisions
between award-seeking films
and non-award-seeking films.

And now, let's get
to the results.

So what I found first
is a 4.7% increase

in the likelihood of hiring
women or racial minority
workers on award-seeking films.

So on the graph on the
right, what you can see

is that before the intervention
and the OscarsSoWhite movement,

there was actually no
difference between the hiring
processes in those two films.

But after the
OscarsSoWhite movement,

there is a bump in
the change that is
sustained by the intervention.

But now that we find this
main effect, what we really

want to know is, are
strategic models at play?

And what I did is I used this
dichotomy between the visible

occupation and the less
visible occupation.

And in line with the
strategic mechanism,

I can see that the
effects are mainly driven
by the visible occupation.

Similarly, if we believe that
the effects are strategic,

we would not expect every
person to benefit from it.

And when I refined
the dependent variable

by looking at the affiliation to
the Academy of Motion Pictures,

what I found is that actually,
unfortunately, the effect

is driven by the workers,
marginalized workers,

that have been invited
to join the Academy.

So taken together, what I
hope to show in those effect

is that we need to
focus further not

only on the direct
effects of intervention,
but also the indirect effects--

especially because
they may have broader

substantial consequences
for the industry--

as well as the importance of
switching the level of analysis

in studying the unintended
consequences of diversity

intervention, not only focusing
on social psychological

mechanisms, but also the
strategic response mechanism
that may occur.

And finally, while previous
research has mainly

focused on how social movements
may target organizations

directly, what I
show is that it's

interesting to look at
how social movements can

target an evaluator to trigger
an industry-wide change.

And I'm very grateful to have
the honor to present here.
Thank you very much.
[APPLAUSE]
